Friday, December 8, 1933

Let's See Some Action
Omicron Delta Kappa has at last initiated, and
the worst and best is known by everyone. Disappointments and gratifications, the conventional reactions, are running their course, but the chief point
of interest to the campus is that now we expect to see
a little utility attaching itself to one of the most
prominent campus institutions.
It is unfortunate that the method of elections to
the group leaves such a few men to begin operations
each year. After graduation last June only four students were left to compose the active membership for
the current year. Recognizing this fact, we have
foreborne to say anything about the apparent inactivity of 0. D. K. during the first two months of this
term. But that excuse will not obtain for very much
longer; we hope to see some constructive programs
forthcoming from the "campus leaders".
The fraternity was originally meant to be a form
of recognition for conspicuous work in extra-curricular activities, but tradition has added to its functions
that of influencing reforms where they are necessary
and of lending powerful support to expedient measures. The opportunity which 0. D. K. has to act in
this capacity is practically unlimited. It has free
access to the services of the most influential men on
the campus and can command the attention of faculty and student body to its projects.
It may be assumed that there is now a sufficiently
representative membership to permit whatever form
of activity may be required. We hope that no delinquency will develop which will force us to repeat the
criticism we made last April, namely, that the boys
were asleep.

A Matter Of Finesse
The sporadic and ludicrous attempts of the more
liberally-minded gentlemen in our midst to convert us
to communistic outlooks are becoming more and more
ineffective with each newly-concocted piece of prop-

aganda. We don't object to being liberalized. We
even confess to being quite conservative in social and
economic matters and to needing a little bit of counterbalancing radicalism.
In evidence of the goodwill which we bear in a
generic way to the pink gentlemen aforementioned,
we dont mind offering a few criticisms of their present methods, which 'are beginning to pall considerably and to offer next to no stimulation whatsoever.
Take, for instance, this tabloid, Toxin Anti-toxin,
which so shocked our sense of literary decency when
it was circulated last week. It was anything but neat;
the best articles could not rise above the level of soapbox prating; and the attacks made upon various fronts
were anything but clever. Any thought which might
have motivated the paper was entirely obscured by the
wretched psychology employed in presenting it. It
was childish.
We return from Thanksgiving recess and find
that the forces of "justice for the oppressed" have
not been sleeping. Nay, rather, they have been losing
a good deal of rest in clandestinely climbing up the
flag-pole to grease it carefully, for the purpose of preventing anyone from taking down the nondescript
rag proclaiming sorrily from the top, "Free the
Scottsboro boys; Death to lynchers." There's drama
for you!
Come now, gentlemen; isn't that rather gross?
There are many notable men whose sentiments are
just as strong as yours who yet would be revolted by
your methods of propaganda. We can be approached
on an intelligent basis and your ideas may be set
forth clearly and forcefully without your having to
indulge in all this clap-trap. It's degrading, if nothing else, to the intellectual foundations of your cause.
Permit yourselves to be human long enough to realize
that to secure a person's support for your projects
you must first gain his confidence.
If you think you have cause whereof to fight
with us, show some decent weapons and come out and
stand your ground. But for pity's sake don't start
throwng pillows.

Killing The Goose
After the exhibition made by the team on Thanksgiving Day against a much heavier St. John's team
we are moved to remind the athletic department again
that unless the schedule is prepared more carefully
next year Hopkins will be the laughing-stock of the
local football circle. Time and again we have been
pitted against teams greatly superior to us and have
received the just rewards of our presumption. As a
general rule we are better-matched with St. John's,
it is true, but as a general principle, our schedule is
not a suitable one.
The idea at the beginning was that by scheduling
some bigger teams we might make enough money to
keep out of the red. This year this income began
to slip away. Very few rooters from U. of M. took
the trouble to watch the Terps whitewash the Jays,
and that's hard on the gate. The fans are quite conscious that the Blue Jays are pretty generally playing out of their class.
To intelligent men only one of two courses is
open: either pay athletes to play for us, as our opponents do; or else retrench our schedule to a more
modest level. The first alternative insults our academic
pride, so the second is the only way out of the dilemna. We have been putting bigger and bigger games
on our schedule until our chances of drawing great
crowds are almost pil. If we don't scale down immediately we'll be in danger of killing the already
strangling goose that was expected to lay golden eggs.

P. B. K. Rules Favorite
A majority preferred a Phi Beta
Kappa key to a varsity letter, one
"because it could be pawned". Favorite college activities included
ping-pong, loafing, dancing and
sleeping (during lectures).
As for the highest campus honor,
about two-thirds favored P. B. K.
The remaining third were divided
between accepting the presidency
of the Student Council and membership in 0. D. K., with the majority preferring 0. D. K.

Season Opens With Match
Away From Home
Tomorrow
Opening an extensive schedule
of dual meets, the Hopkins wrestling team will encounter Washington and Lee University tomorrow
evening at Lexington, Virginia.
After many weeks of practice,
Coach Tubby Miller has rounded
out a team composed both of veterans and newcomers. Two regulars of last year, Bill Bourne,
heavyweight, and Croxton McDaniel, 155 lbs., will be unable to represent Hopkins tomorrow night
due to injuries.
Line-up For Contest

Other veterans who will be in
uniform against Washington and
Lee are Capt. Phil Hartman, Bill
Grauer, and George Mitchell.
The meet should be a hard test
for the Jay grapplers, as the Virginians have a very strong team.
Probable Hopkins team:

165-1b. class—George Mitchell
175-1b. clsas—George Connor
Heavyweight—Harrison Davies.

year's varsity members failed to
appear. The squad will meet every Monday, Wednesday, and Friday at the pool.

Friday, December 8, 1933

Let's See Some Action
Omicron Delta Kappa has at last initiated, and
the worst and best is known by everyone. Disappointments and gratifications, the conventional reactions, are running their course, but the chief point
of interest to the campus is that now we expect to see
a little utility attaching itself to one of the most
prominent campus institutions.
It is unfortunate that the method of elections to
the group leaves such a few men to begin operations
each year. After graduation last June only four students were left to compose the active membership for
the current year. Recognizing this fact, we have
foreborne to say anything about the apparent inactivity of 0. D. K. during the first two months of this
term. But that excuse will not obtain for very much
longer; we hope to see some constructive programs
forthcoming from the "campus leaders".
The fraternity was originally meant to be a form
of recognition for conspicuous work in extra-curricular activities, but tradition has added to its functions
that of influencing reforms where they are necessary
and of lending powerful support to expedient measures. The opportunity which 0. D. K. has to act in
this capacity is practically unlimited. It has free
access to the services of the most influential men on
the campus and can command the attention of faculty and student body to its projects.
It may be assumed that there is now a sufficiently
representative membership to permit whatever form
of activity may be required. We hope that no delinquency will develop which will force us to repeat the
criticism we made last April, namely, that the boys
were asleep.

A Matter Of Finesse
The sporadic and ludicrous attempts of the more
liberally-minded gentlemen in our midst to convert us
to communistic outlooks are becoming more and more
ineffective with each newly-concocted piece of prop-

aganda. We don't object to being liberalized. We
even confess to being quite conservative in social and
economic matters and to needing a little bit of counterbalancing radicalism.
In evidence of the goodwill which we bear in a
generic way to the pink gentlemen aforementioned,
we dont mind offering a few criticisms of their present methods, which 'are beginning to pall considerably and to offer next to no stimulation whatsoever.
Take, for instance, this tabloid, Toxin Anti-toxin,
which so shocked our sense of literary decency when
it was circulated last week. It was anything but neat;
the best articles could not rise above the level of soapbox prating; and the attacks made upon various fronts
were anything but clever. Any thought which might
have motivated the paper was entirely obscured by the
wretched psychology employed in presenting it. It
was childish.
We return from Thanksgiving recess and find
that the forces of "justice for the oppressed" have
not been sleeping. Nay, rather, they have been losing
a good deal of rest in clandestinely climbing up the
flag-pole to grease it carefully, for the purpose of preventing anyone from taking down the nondescript
rag proclaiming sorrily from the top, "Free the
Scottsboro boys; Death to lynchers." There's drama
for you!
Come now, gentlemen; isn't that rather gross?
There are many notable men whose sentiments are
just as strong as yours who yet would be revolted by
your methods of propaganda. We can be approached
on an intelligent basis and your ideas may be set
forth clearly and forcefully without your having to
indulge in all this clap-trap. It's degrading, if nothing else, to the intellectual foundations of your cause.
Permit yourselves to be human long enough to realize
that to secure a person's support for your projects
you must first gain his confidence.
If you think you have cause whereof to fight
with us, show some decent weapons and come out and
stand your ground. But for pity's sake don't start
throwng pillows.

Killing The Goose
After the exhibition made by the team on Thanksgiving Day against a much heavier St. John's team
we are moved to remind the athletic department again
that unless the schedule is prepared more carefully
next year Hopkins will be the laughing-stock of the
local football circle. Time and again we have been
pitted against teams greatly superior to us and have
received the just rewards of our presumption. As a
general rule we are better-matched with St. John's,
it is true, but as a general principle, our schedule is
not a suitable one.
The idea at the beginning was that by scheduling
some bigger teams we might make enough money to
keep out of the red. This year this income began
to slip away. Very few rooters from U. of M. took
the trouble to watch the Terps whitewash the Jays,
and that's hard on the gate. The fans are quite conscious that the Blue Jays are pretty generally playing out of their class.
To intelligent men only one of two courses is
open: either pay athletes to play for us, as our opponents do; or else retrench our schedule to a more
modest level. The first alternative insults our academic
pride, so the second is the only way out of the dilemna. We have been putting bigger and bigger games
on our schedule until our chances of drawing great
crowds are almost pil. If we don't scale down immediately we'll be in danger of killing the already
strangling goose that was expected to lay golden eggs.

P. B. K. Rules Favorite
A majority preferred a Phi Beta
Kappa key to a varsity letter, one
"because it could be pawned". Favorite college activities included
ping-pong, loafing, dancing and
sleeping (during lectures).
As for the highest campus honor,
about two-thirds favored P. B. K.
The remaining third were divided
between accepting the presidency
of the Student Council and membership in 0. D. K., with the majority preferring 0. D. K.

Season Opens With Match
Away From Home
Tomorrow
Opening an extensive schedule
of dual meets, the Hopkins wrestling team will encounter Washington and Lee University tomorrow
evening at Lexington, Virginia.
After many weeks of practice,
Coach Tubby Miller has rounded
out a team composed both of veterans and newcomers. Two regulars of last year, Bill Bourne,
heavyweight, and Croxton McDaniel, 155 lbs., will be unable to represent Hopkins tomorrow night
due to injuries.
Line-up For Contest

Other veterans who will be in
uniform against Washington and
Lee are Capt. Phil Hartman, Bill
Grauer, and George Mitchell.
The meet should be a hard test
for the Jay grapplers, as the Virginians have a very strong team.

appear. The squad will meet every Monday, Wednesday, and Friday at the pool.
